What is the difference between a deductible and an out-of-pocket maximum?

A deductible is the amount you pay for covered services before the plan starts paying. An out-of-pocket maximum is the most you will pay in a policy period for covered services; after you reach it, the plan pays 100% of covered costs (subject to policy terms and exclusions).

How do I add my spouse to my auto policy?

To add your spouse, request a policy update and provide their driver's license number, date of birth, and driving history. We'll verify eligibility, update listed drivers, and confirm any premium changes before the endorsement is finalized.

What documents do I need to file a homeowners claim for roof damage?

Typically you'll need photos of the damage, the date and cause (e.g., storm), any repair estimates or invoices, and your policy number. If safe, prevent further damage (e.g., tarp) and keep receipts for mitigation expenses.

Can I bundle home and auto insurance to save money?
Yes. Bundling home and auto often qualifies for a multi-policy discount. Savings vary by state, coverage levels, and risk factors; we can quote both policies together to estimate the discount.

What is an endorsement on an insurance policy?
An endorsement is a written change to your policy that adds, removes, or modifies coverage. It becomes part of the policy and can affect premium and terms.

How does accident forgiveness work?

Accident forgiveness is an optional benefit that may prevent your premium from increasing after your first qualifying at-fault accident. Eligibility rules apply, such as a clean driving record for a set period and the accident meeting program criteria.

Do you offer gap insurance for car loans?

Yes, gap coverage can help pay the difference between what you owe on your auto loan/lease and the vehicle's actual cash value if it's totaled. Availability and limits depend on your state and underwriting guidelines.

What is actual cash value versus replacement cost for property coverage?

Actual cash value (ACV) generally equals replacement cost minus depreciation. Replacement cost coverage pays to repair/replace with like kind and quality without deducting depreciation, subject to policy limits and conditions.

How do I update my address on my life insurance policy?

You can update your address through your online account or by contacting support. We'll verify your identity, update mailing/primary residence information, and send confirmation once the change is processed.

What is the difference between term life and whole life insurance?

Term life provides coverage for a specific period (e.g., 10-30 years) and typically has lower premiums. Whole life is permanent coverage with a cash value component and level premiums, subject to policy details.

How long does it take to receive a claim payment?

Timing varies by claim type and complexity, but once coverage is confirmed and required documentation is received, many claims are paid within 5-10 business days. Large losses or third-party coordination can take longer.

What is underwriting?

Underwriting is the process of evaluating risk to determine eligibility, coverage terms, and pricing. It may consider factors like driving history, property characteristics, medical information (for life), and claim history.

Can I pay my premium monthly instead of annually?
Yes. Many policies offer monthly, quarterly, or semi-annual billing. Some payment plans may include installment fees; we can review available options for your policy.

What happens if my payment is late?

If a payment is late, your policy may enter a grace period depending on the product and state rules. If payment isn't received by the end of the grace period, coverage could lapse. Contact us as soon as possible to avoid interruption.

How do I set up autopay?
Log in to your account, open Billing, select Autopay, and choose a bank account or card. We'll show the draft date and send a confirmation once autopay is active.

Does renters insurance cover stolen items from my car?

Often yes, personal property coverage may apply to items stolen from your vehicle, subject to policy limits, deductible, and exclusions. Auto insurance may also apply depending on circumstances; we can help determine the best claim path.

What is liability coverage on an auto policy?
Liability coverage helps pay for injuries or property damage you cause to others in an accident. It typically includes bodily injury liability and property damage liability, each with its own limit.

What is uninsured/underinsured motorist coverage?
UM/UIM helps cover your injuries (and in some states property damage) if you're hit by a driver who has no insurance or not enough insurance. Coverage, limits, and availability vary by state.

How do I get proof of insurance?
You can download an ID card from your online account or mobile app. If you need it emailed or mailed, contact support and we can send proof of insurance to you.

What is a beneficiary on a life insurance policy?
A beneficiary is the person or entity you name to receive the death benefit when the insured passes away. You can usually update beneficiaries at any time, subject to policy rules.

Can I change my beneficiary online?
In many cases, yes. Log in and navigate to Policy Details > Beneficiaries. Some changes may require additional verification or a signed form depending on policy type and state requirements.

What is an HSA and how does it work with insurance?

A Health Savings Account (HSA) is a tax-advantaged account used to pay qualified medical expenses. It's typically paired with an HSA-eligible high-deductible health plan; contributions can be used for eligible out-of-pocket costs.

Do you offer annuities?

Yes, we offer fixed annuities in select states. Annuities can provide tax-deferred growth and may offer guaranteed income options. Product features, fees, and surrender charges vary; review the contract for details.

What is a surrender charge on an annuity?
A surrender charge is a fee that may apply if you withdraw more than the free-withdrawal amount or cancel the annuity during the surrender period. The charge typically declines over time.

How is my auto premium calculated?
Premiums are based on factors like driving record, vehicle type, mileage, garaging address, coverage limits, deductibles, and applicable discounts. State laws and rating rules also influence pricing.

What discounts are available for auto insurance?
Common discounts include multi-policy, safe driver, paid-in-full, paperless, anti-theft, and good student (where available). Eligibility varies by state and underwriting guidelines.

Does homeowners insurance cover flooding?
Standard homeowners policies typically exclude flood damage. Flood coverage is generally purchased separately through a flood policy or specialty endorsement, depending on eligibility and location.

Do I need earthquake coverage?

Earthquake coverage is optional and depends on your location and risk tolerance. Standard homeowners policies usually exclude earthquake damage; you can add an endorsement or separate policy where available.

What does umbrella insurance cover?

Umbrella insurance provides additional liability protection above your underlying home/auto limits. It can help cover legal defense and damages for certain claims, subject to exclusions and required underlying limits.

How do I file a claim after a car accident?

Ensure everyone is safe, call emergency services if needed, exchange information, and document the scene. Then report the claim with the date/time, location, parties involved, photos, and a brief description. We'll assign an adjuster and guide next steps.

What is subrogation?

Subrogation is when your insurer seeks reimbursement from the at-fault party (or their insurer) after paying a covered claim. If recovered, you may receive your deductible back depending on state rules and recovery amount.

Can I get a refund if I cancel my policy mid-term?

Many policies are eligible for a prorated refund if canceled mid-term, minus any earned premium and applicable fees as allowed by state rules. The exact amount depends on your policy type and cancellation date.

What is a declarations page?
The declarations page summarizes your policy: named insureds, coverages, limits, deductibles, policy period, and premium. It's a quick reference for key policy details.

How do I update my vehicle on my auto policy?
To replace or add a vehicle, provide the VIN, year/make/model, purchase date, lienholder (if any), and mileage. We'll update coverages and confirm your new premium and effective date.

Does life insurance require a medical exam?
Some policies require a medical exam, while others may offer accelerated underwriting based on health questions and data checks. Requirements vary by product, age, and coverage amount.

What is a premium waiver rider?
A premium waiver rider may waive or reimburse premiums if you become totally disabled and meet the policy's definition and waiting period. Availability depends on the life product and state rules.

How do I make an extra payment toward my auto loan?

You can make an extra principal payment through your loan portal or by contacting servicing. Specify that the payment should be applied to principal (if supported) and confirm how it affects your next due date.

What is APR on a loan?

APR (Annual Percentage Rate) reflects the yearly cost of borrowing, including interest and certain fees, expressed as a percentage. It can help compare loan offers more consistently than interest rate alone.

How do I set up a Roth IRA contribution?

You can set up contributions by linking a bank account and scheduling recurring transfers, or making one-time deposits. Contribution limits and eligibility depend on income and tax filing status; confirm current IRS rules.

What is the difference between a traditional IRA and Roth IRA?

Traditional IRA contributions may be tax-deductible (depending on eligibility) and withdrawals are taxed in retirement. Roth IRA contributions are made with after-tax dollars and qualified withdrawals can be tax-free, subject to IRS rules.

Can I roll over a 401(k) into an IRA?

Often yes. A direct rollover moves funds from your 401(k) to an IRA without withholding taxes. You'll typically need to open/identify the receiving IRA and request the rollover through your plan administrator.

What is a 529 plan?

A 529 plan is a tax-advantaged account designed to save for qualified education expenses. Earnings can grow tax-deferred and withdrawals used for qualified expenses may be tax-free, subject to state and federal rules.

How do I insure a new small business?

We start with your business type, revenue, payroll, locations, and operations to recommend coverages such as general liability, property, workers' comp (if required), and professional liability. Then we provide quotes based on underwriting.

What is workers' compensation insurance?
Workers' comp helps cover medical costs and lost wages for employees injured on the job and can provide employer liability protection. Requirements vary by state and by number of employees.

What does professional liability insurance cover?

Professional liability (errors & omissions) can help cover claims alleging negligence or mistakes in professional services, including certain legal defense costs and damages, subject to policy terms and exclusions.

How do I dispute a claim decision?

You can request a review by contacting claims support and providing any additional documentation (photos, estimates, reports). We'll explain the decision, re-evaluate new information, and outline any formal appeal options available in your state.

What is a policy lapse and how can I reinstate coverage?

A lapse occurs when coverage ends due to nonpayment or nonrenewal. Reinstatement may be possible by paying the balance due and meeting any underwriting requirements. Availability and effective dates depend on product and state rules.

Do you offer identity theft protection?

How do I add a driver to my policy who has an international license?

We can review eligibility based on your state rules and the driver's licensing status. Typically we'll need a copy of the license, driving history if available, and expected driving frequency. We may require conversion to a local license within a set timeframe.

What is the difference between collision and comprehensive coverage?

Collision helps pay for damage to your vehicle from an accident with a vehicle or object. Comprehensive covers non-collision losses like theft, vandalism, hail, or animal impact, each subject to your deductible and policy terms.

How do I request an insurance binder?

Contact your agent or support with the policy details and the party requesting the binder (e.g., lender). We'll issue a temporary proof of coverage showing effective date, limits, and insured parties.
